questions.model_answer:
(a) Start with the expression: 

$$x^2 + 10x + 2$$

Use the identity:

$$(x + \dfrac{b}{2})^2 = x^2 + bx + \left(\dfrac{b}{2}\right)^2$$

Apply it with $$b = 10$$:

$$x^2 + 10x + 2 = (x + \dfrac{10}{2})^2 - (\dfrac{10}{2})^2 + 2$$

$$= (x + 5)^2 - 25 + 2$$

$$= (x + 5)^2 - 23$$ \hfill (2)

(b) The turning point of a quadratic in the form $$y = (x + a)^2 + b$$ is at $$(-a, b)$$

So for $$y = (x + 5)^2 - 23$$, the turning point is $$(-5, -23)$$ \hfill (1)
questions.question_description: Convert a quadratic expression into completed square form and identify the turning point of the graph.

questions.model_answer:
(a) Start with the expression: 

$$x^2 - 6x + 25$$

Use the identity:

$$(x + \dfrac{b}{2})^2 = x^2 + bx + \left(\dfrac{b}{2}\right)^2$$

Apply it with $$b = -6$$:

$$x^2 - 6x + 25 = (x + \dfrac{-6}{2})^2 - \left(\dfrac{-6}{2}\right)^2 + 25$$

$$= (x - 3)^2 - 9 + 25$$

$$= (x - 3)^2 + 16$$ \hfill (2)

(b) The turning point of a quadratic in the form $$y = (x + a)^2 + b$$ is at $$(-a, b)$$

So for $$y = (x - 3)^2 + 16$$, the turning point is $$(3, 16)$$ \hfill (1)
